#  Defining a function that will give percentages for countplots without the hue parameter
def without_hue(plot, feature):
    total = len(feature)
    for p in ax.patches:
        percentage = '{:.1f}%'.format(100 * p.get_height()/total)
        x = p.get_x() + p.get_width() / 2 - 0.05
        y = p.get_y() + p.get_height()
        ax.annotate(percentage, (x, y), size = 12)
    plt.show()
def without_hueh(plot, feature):
    total = len(feature)
    for p in ax.patches:
        percentage = '{:.1f}%'.format(100 * p.get_width()/total)
        y = p.get_y() + p.get_height() / 2 - 0.05
        x = p.get_x() + p.get_width()
        ax.annotate(percentage, (x, y), size = 12)
    plt.show()
source.e66f9434:
#  Defining a function that will give percentages for countplots with the hue parameter
def with_hue(plot, feature, Number_of_categories, hue_categories):
    a = [p.get_height() for p in plot.patches]
    patch = [p for p in plot.patches]
    for i in range(Number_of_categories):
        total = feature.value_counts().values[i]
        for j in range(hue_categories):
            percentage = '{:.1f}%'.format(100 * a[(j*Number_of_categories + i)]/total)
            x = patch[(j*Number_of_categories + i)].get_x() + patch[(j*Number_of_categories + i)].get_width() / 2 - 0.15
            y = patch[(j*Number_of_categories + i)].get_y() + patch[(j*Number_of_categories + i)].get_height() 
            ax.annotate(percentage, (x, y), size = 12)
    plt.show()

# Question 5

labels =['Student','Data Scientist','Software Engineer','Other','Data Analyst','Not employed',
         'Research Scientist','ML Engineer', 'BA','PPM','DE','PM','S','DBA','DR'] 
sizes = kaggle_tidy.Q5.value_counts()
perc = [f'{i/sizes.sum()*100:5.2f}%' for i in sizes]
lbl = [f'{el[0]} = {el[1]}' for el in zip(labels, perc)]

cmap = matplotlib.cm.Blues
mini=min(sizes)
maxi=max(sizes)
norm = matplotlib.colors.Normalize(vmin=mini, vmax=maxi)
colors = [cmap(norm(value)) for value in sizes]

plt.figure(figsize=(14,8), dpi= 80)
squarify.plot(sizes=sizes, label=lbl, color=colors,alpha=1,pad = True,
              text_kwargs={'fontsize':8, 'fontname':"Trebuchet MS",'weight':'bold'})

plt.title('Treemap of Current Role', fontsize =20, bbox={'facecolor':'0.7', 'pad':5})
plt.axis('off')
plt.show()

#  Defining a function to group salaries into smaller categories
def salary_class(salary_grup):
    if salary_grup['Q25']=='$0-999':
        return '< $1K'
    elif (salary_grup['Q25']=='1,000-1,999'or
         salary_grup['Q25']=='2,000-2,999'or
         salary_grup['Q25']=='3,000-3,999'or
         salary_grup['Q25']=='4,000-4,999'or
         salary_grup['Q25']=='5,000-7,499'or
         salary_grup['Q25']=='7,500-9,999'):
        return '1-10K'
    elif (salary_grup['Q25']=='10,000-14,999'or
          salary_grup['Q25']=='15,000-19,999'or
          salary_grup['Q25']=='20,000-24,999'):
         return '10-25K'
    elif (salary_grup['Q25']=='25,000-29,999'or
          salary_grup['Q25']=='30,000-39,999'or
          salary_grup['Q25']=='40,000-49,999'):
         return '25-50K'
    elif (salary_grup['Q25']=='50,000-59,999'or
          salary_grup['Q25']=='60,000-69,999'or
          salary_grup['Q25']=='70,000-79,999'or
          salary_grup['Q25']=='80,000-89,999'or
          salary_grup['Q25']=='90,000-99,999'):
        return '50-100K'
    elif (salary_grup['Q25']=='100,000-124,999'or
          salary_grup['Q25']=='125,000-149,999'or
          salary_grup['Q25']=='150,000-199,999'or
          salary_grup['Q25']=='200,000-249,999'):
          
        return '100-250K'
    elif (salary_grup['Q25']=='250,000-299,999'or
          salary_grup['Q25']=='300,000-499,999'):
                  
        return '250-500K'
    
    elif (salary_grup['Q25']=='$500,000-999,999'or
          salary_grup['Q25']=='>$1,000,000'):
                  
        return '>500K'
                
salary_grouped= kaggle_tidy.apply(salary_class ,axis='columns') 
kaggle_tidy['salary_group'] =pd.Series(salary_grouped)

# Question 5

labels =['Student','Data Scientist','Data Analyst','Not employed','Other','Software Engineer',
         'ML Engineer','Research Scientist','BA', 'PPM','S','DE', 'PM','DBA','DR'] 
sizes = Afri.Q5.value_counts()
perc = [f'{i/sizes.sum()*100:5.2f}%' for i in sizes]
lbl = [f'{el[0]} = {el[1]}' for el in zip(labels, perc)]

cmap = matplotlib.cm.Blues
mini=min(sizes)
maxi=max(sizes)
norm = matplotlib.colors.Normalize(vmin=mini, vmax=maxi)
colors = [cmap(norm(value)) for value in sizes]

plt.figure(figsize=(13,7), dpi= 100)
squarify.plot(sizes=sizes, label=lbl, color=colors,alpha=0.8,pad = True,
              text_kwargs={'fontsize':9, 'fontname':"Trebuchet MS",'weight':'bold'})

plt.title('Treemap of Current Role', fontsize =20, bbox={'facecolor':'0.7', 'pad':5})
plt.axis('off')
plt.show()

source.19a9650b: ##### 15.9% of the respondents do not make use of BI products. Participants who use BI tools use Tableau (9.9%) followed closely by Microsoft Power BI at 9.3%. In the next two years we have got more respondents will to learn a BI product than those who chose none at all. These aspire to learn Tableau, Microsoft Power BI and Google Data Studio in that order.
source.0edfa895: ##### Amazon Simple storage service is the commonly used by 8.9% of the respondents, followed by Goggle Cloud Storage with 7.5%. There is quite a portion (5.8%) of individuals who do not use data cloud data storage products
source.4c9bb1ef: #####  Approximately 38% of employers are either exploring or have started using ML methods in their business. 13.1% of participants' employers are still exploring using ML methodswith 12.6% not use ML methods at all. Interestingly 10.4% of the respondents do not know if their employers are using or exploring ML methods. It might be worthwhile just checking their titles at those organisations
source.6e640bad: ##### More people have or are aspiring to have a Master's degree followed by a Bachelor's degree with fewer people preferring not to disclose their education level . Around 90% of survey participants have at least a bachelor’s degree, pointing to learned people willing to improve on their learning and knowledge through Kaggle.
source.fb664436: ##### From the above 3 graphs we can see easily that Data Scientist have got more experience in using ML methods, especically from 2 years upwards. Though the Asian continent has the largest numbers for years of experience less than 5, Europe has higher numbers for years above 5 years. source.ae7f64a5: # Introduction In this report we are going to look at what is happening in the machine learning community and draw insights about a typical person who makes use of Kaggle. With these insights, we hope to help young and upcoming individuals who are passionate about data science to break into this relatively new, interdisciplinary field of statistics, computer science, mathematics and engineering. We will first analyse the whole dataset to draw a worldwide view of this field, looking for correlations and certain patterns. In the second part, we will look at the continent of Africa and try to position it relative to others in the data science field. The continent has often been accused for lagging behind in most areas. If so, by how far and what can be done to improve. According to Mybroadband, academic institutions in Africa have only recently begun to catch up. Some are creating structures, networks and training programmes to stimulate research and capacity development in the subject. Our aim is to see if our survey can show us if there is a huge difference between participants from Africa and the rest of the world in terms of experience and education. We have deliberately looked at almost any possible cross tabulations to gain insights and also gain knowledge on the subject matter as this is my first notebook being shared publicly.

source.2a913742:
Strides have been made to help to grow the data science field in Africa over the past few years. We will mention a few of them that have been implemented in helping data science improve in the continent. According to Data Science Africa they have trained over 200 participants on cutting edge machine learning techniques and data science applications. Their participants had diverse backgrounds including undergraduate and graduate students, researchers and industry players interested in learning how to apply cutting edge methods to the problems they care about.

According to News Medical of October 2021, a new programme (2021) worth $74.5 million by the United States National Institutes of Health is going to advance data science, spark innovation and spur health discoveries on the continent. AIMS is a post-graduate education network and research institute with five centres in South Africa, Senegal, Ghana, Cameroon and Rwanda that served as the regional hub for this project in Africa and aligned the focus of its work to the African.

DataHack4FI also holds competitions since 2018. The competitions are held in seven countries (Ghana, Kenya, Nigeria, Rwanda, South Africa, Uganda and Zambia). Another platform is Zindi, that hosts a community of more than 30,000 data scientists in a bid to access African datasets and solve African problems. The list is not exhaustive but to highlight the initiatives that have been done and are ongoing.

**The question to be answered, is have these initiatives helped to bridge the lag in the data science field. We hope the analysis below on African participants in the Kaggle Survey will help to see how big the gap is in terms of experience in programming and advanced technology in the field, education and  their compensation.**

source.f5bf0bf9: ## 3 Findings and Recommendations ### Findings From the insights gathered from the data available, the continent is not very far off thanks to efforts that have been implemented over the past few years. However, they are few areas that need to be addressed in the short to medium term. Below are the findings: 1. Africa has slighty more representation (20.1%)for the female gender than the rest of the world(18.8%). However this is needs to be improved starting now. 2. Category for those not employed has the fourth highest respondents whereas for the rest of the world its 5th. This might point to high unemployment rates on the continent 3. Respondents with Bachelors degree are 11% more than those with a Masters. Comparetively the world has a difference of 0.9% between the two. 4. Most participants only know one programming language, whereas for the rest of the world most participants know two They also have fewer years of experience in both programming languages and ML 5. More respondents in Africa have never used specialised hardware or TPUs. Those that have are less when compared to the world. This is also true for Computer Vision and NLP methods. 6. More people who have less than two years or have never used ML methods but less for 2+ years. 7. African respondents earn less than their counterparts. Most earn below USD 10k per annum as compared to about USD50K. 8. Organisations have spent less for amounts above USD 1K on ML and CCPs. 9. More organisations that do not use ML methods and less for those using the methods. On a positive note slighlty more companies (14.6%) are exploring the use of ML compared to 13.1% 10. Given that Africa is the second largest continent in the world. Its country respresentation of 17.8% in is very low. ### Recomendations We welcome the efforts that have been done by the organisations mentioned in the introduction in propping data science in Africa. However, it is of our opinion that this should be done at country level as well. Some universities on the continent have done a great deal in putting out degrees in the data field and AI. According to a quote on University World News, universities in Uganda do not have data science courses. This might also be true for several countries. In my home country, Zimbabwe, they have various degrees in data science but due to low economic activity, these young graduates might never get to practise their skills. 1. We are aware that you cannot buy experience with money. However, a strategy for medium to long term will be to start programming in primary and high schools alluded above. We feel curriculums on data science should be introduction at these levels as coding classes. Young children should build love and curiosity for data science at a tender age. This will create awareness of such a field. As we grew up, most learners wanted to be teachers or doctors because they were well spoken of during lessons. Huge corporates and high schools should introduce career guidance on data science. 2. We encourage data science aspirants to continue learning. Those with resources must aim to attain the highest qualifications possible. For those without, they must look for funded initiatives, short courses, free courses offered by Kaggle and subsidised courses being offered by Google during this COVID period. More platforms to produce free and open educational resources to help those that are less privileged. As the amount of data continues to rise on a daily based the need for specialised hardware ,advanced technologies, big data and cloud platforms can not be overstated. Data Scientists (novices and experts) must invest in learning these. 3. Governments must provide subsidies for electronic gadgets and internet for all schools including those in rural areas. They can also rope in huge corporations. Governments and companies should be made aware that data science is important for economic growth through improved service and treatments in the medical fields 4. It is our opinion that a good data scientist should know at least two programming, one for big data and one cloud computing platform. 5. Organisations are reluctant to invest in data science, maybe fearing the outlays that might be involved. However, sitting on valuable data is even more expensive as you lose competitive edge or miss new ways of treating diseases or conserving the environment just to mention a few. We feel most organisations lack a data culture especially at management and executive level. Platforms for data science need to hold regular seminars or courses for executives and management in both private and public sectors on the advantages of making data-driven decisions. We can’t agree more with a quote by Juan H. Klopper, a specialist surgeon at South Africa’s Stellenbosch University that “Data answers questions about our world, and is a path to finding solutions to our problems.
